item.title: Evaluating a Limit as a Riemann Sum
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: In calculus, taking the Riemann sum is a method of approximating the area under a curve over a specific interval - it's a way to estimate a definite integral. In this post, I will describe how a Riemann sum can be used to evaluate the limit at infinity of a specific type of sum.

item.title: Teaching ARGO to Generate Emotions using Machine Learning
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: Now that ARGO has been completed, we'd like to teach ARGO to learn to generate emotions. It turns out that Machine Learning principles can be used to do train a model to do this. Specifically, a discriminative model of emotion can be used to train a generative model that allows ARGO to learn to generate expressions of anger, happiness, sadness, and surprise. This post gives an overview of the generative model training process, followed by detailed explanations of each step.

item.title: Meet ARGO! Part 2
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: In this post, I describe the software used to control ARGOâ€™s systems. Learn how to install and use the NXT Python and ServoBlaster packages to track human faces and express facial emotion with ARGO!

item.title: Meet ARGO! Part 1
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: Meet ARGO, an emotionally intelligent robot made of Legos. ARGO (Anthropomorphic Recognition and Generation Objective) is a multi-system robot that can be trained to recognize and generate facial expressions. I built ARGO as part of my science fair project this year to investigate the field of Emotion Artificial Intelligence.

item.title: Delivery! Python-Compatible Packages for Emotion Recognition
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: When learning how to install and use an open-source package, one might swim through a myriad of articles and blog posts, among other information sources, only to find oneself even more confused. Given all the complications that may arise, I have written an simple guide for installation of the OpenCV and Dlib packages with Python compatibility.

item.title: Training a Physiologically Based Model for Emotion Recognition
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: Emotion recognition is a vital part of our lives. Currently, computers and most robots are incapable of recognizing emotions. How would our lives change if a computer could understand when we're happy or sad? And what if a computer could actually learn to recognize emotions? It turns out that machine learning (ML) can be used to teach a computer to do so.

item.title: Affective Computing in a Nutshell
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: Often, when we consider a scenario in which computers interact with humans, we imagine a disastrous result- the computer, equipped with newfound superhuman intelligence and power obliterates its human creators. But is this really the case? The ideas of affective computing argue otherwise.

item.title: Breaking Down the Facial Action Coding System (FACS)
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: When analyzing facial expressions, is there a standardized way to describe one's facial movements? The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) is a method of doing so. But what exactly is FACS?

item.title: Lie to Me: Micro-expressions Explained
item.dc:creator: pybeebee
item.description: The show "Lie to Me" may seem like a typical American crime drama series- Dr. Cal Lightman and his co-workers at the Lightman Group work with law enforcement agencies to solve crimes. But upon looking more carefully at how the crimes are solved, we might be in for a fascinating surprise.
